content: The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission with specific purposes, composition, duties, powers, and staff provisions. It also includes sections on compensation, security clearances, reports, and authorization of appropriations. The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel is established by the Act with specific purposes, composition, duties, powers, and staff provisions. The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel is established to evaluate potential improvements in the US approach to radioactive waste management if the Yucca Mountain repository is not operational. It will submit a report to Congress with findings and recommendations to enhance the management of defense waste. The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel will submit a report to Congress with findings and recommendations to improve the management of defense waste, spent nuclear fuel, high-level waste, and commercial radioactive waste. The Commission is tasked with evaluating alternatives to the Federal Government's spent fuel and high-level waste strategies, including transferring responsibility to a Government corporation. The Commission is evaluating alternatives to the Federal Government's management of high-level radioactive waste and spent fuel, including transferring responsibility to a Government corporation with authority and funding for storage and management. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, and administer oaths as needed. It can also enter into contracts to fulfill its duties and obtain information from federal agencies. The Commission can obtain information from federal agencies to fulfill its duties under this Act. Each member of the Commission may be compensated at a daily rate not exceeding the annual rate of basic pay for a position at level IV of the Executive Schedule. Travel expenses, including per diem, will be provided for Commission members while away from their home or regular place of business. When performing services for the Commission, a member is allowed travel expenses, including per diem, similar to intermittent government employees under section 5703(b) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 10. SECURITY CLEARANCES. The Federal agencies shall cooperate with the Commission to provide appropriate security clearances to members and staff. No access to classified information without clearances. SEC. 11. REPORTS. The Commission will release an interim report for public comment within 1 year of the Act's enactment, and a final report to Congress within 2 years of its first meeting, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations agreed upon by the majority of members. The final report to Congress will include items agreed upon by the majority of the Commission, opinions of dissenting members with explanations, and consideration of public comments. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Act, with funds available until expended. The Commission's authority terminates 180 days after the final report submission, during which they can conclude activities and disseminate the report.
